title: Synthetic Recap
body:
TORONTO (AP) — On a night where offense was a precious commodity, one man staged a historic performance for the ages. Grant Hill of the Detroit Pistons didn’t just carry his team; he authored a masterpiece, pouring in a staggering 46 points to will the Pistons to a 93-83 victory over the Toronto Raptors.

In a grinding, physical contest where no other player on either side managed more than 17 points, Hill was a symphony of scoring. He was relentless, attacking the rim with an elegance and force that the Raptors had no answer for. While his teammates combined for just 47 points, Hill nearly matched them single-handedly, his will becoming the Pistons' primary offensive system.

Toronto, led by Doug Christie's 17 points, simply watched the legend unfold. They tried every defender, every scheme, but the outcome was the same: Hill finding a way. His 46-point eruption wasn't just a high-scoring game; it was a lifeline for a team struggling to find its rhythm, a one-man rescue mission executed with breathtaking precision.

The final score, a 10-point Pistons win, is a deception. This was not a team victory; it was the Grant Hill Game. He didn't just lead the stat sheet; he dominated the very narrative of the night, delivering a performance so monumental that it will be remembered long after the season's final standings are forgotten. In the annals of Pistons history, this was Hill’s night, a brilliant, singular force of nature.
